evidence_passages.title: The Storm
evidence_passages.text: Thunder rumbled in the distance as Maya hurried home. The sky had turned an ominous shade of gray, and the wind whipped her hair across her face. She clutched her backpack tightly, remembering the weather report's warning about possible tornadoes. Her heart pounded as she spotted the familiar red door of her house just two blocks away.
evidence_passages.question: How does Maya feel about the approaching storm?

evidence_passages.title: The Competition
evidence_passages.text: Jordan had trained for this moment for three years. As she approached the starting blocks, she noticed her main rival, Chen, stretching nearby. They exchanged a brief nod—respectful but competitive. Jordan's coach had always said, 'Your biggest competition is yourself.' Today, she would prove him right by beating her personal record.
evidence_passages.question: What is the relationship between Jordan and Chen?
evidence_passages.evidence: They exchanged a brief nod—respectful but competitive

theme_passages.title: The Unexpected Teacher
theme_passages.text: Marcus thought he had nothing to learn from his elderly neighbor, Mr. Patterson. But when his phone died and he needed directions, Mr. Patterson taught him to read a paper map. When the power went out, Mr. Patterson showed him how to cook on a camp stove. When Marcus was stressed about exams, Mr. Patterson taught him chess to clear his mind. By summer's end, Marcus realized that wisdom comes in many forms, and age is just a number.
theme_passages.theme: Wisdom can come from unexpected sources
development: Mr. Patterson teaches practical skills (map reading, cooking)
Mr. Patterson helps with mental wellbeing (chess)
Marcus changes his perspective by the end

theme_passages.title: The Group Project
theme_passages.text: When Ms. Rivera assigned random groups, Aaliyah groaned. She was paired with three students she'd never talked to: a quiet artist, an outspoken athlete, and a new student from another country. At first, their meetings were awkward and unproductive. But as they listened to each other's ideas, something changed. The artist visualized their concepts. The athlete organized their timeline. The new student brought a fresh perspective. Their final presentation earned the highest grade—and Aaliyah learned that diverse teams create the strongest results.
development: Aaliyah is disappointed with her random group

informational_passages.title: The Ocean Cleanup Challenge
informational_passages.text: Every year, approximately 8 million metric tons of plastic enter our oceans. This plastic harms marine life, contaminates seafood, and affects human health. However, innovative solutions are emerging. Young inventor Boyan Slat designed a passive cleanup system that uses ocean currents to collect plastic. Communities worldwide are organizing beach cleanups. Scientists are developing bacteria that can break down plastics. While the challenge is immense, the combination of technology, community action, and scientific research offers hope for cleaner oceans.
informational_passages.central_idea: The ocean plastic problem is serious, but innovative solutions are emerging

informational_passages.title: Sleep and the Teenage Brain
informational_passages.text: Teenagers need 8-10 hours of sleep per night, yet most get fewer than 7. This isn't just about feeling tired—sleep deprivation affects memory, mood, and academic performance. During sleep, the brain consolidates learning from the day. The teenage brain is still developing, making adequate sleep even more critical. Schools that have shifted to later start times report improved attendance, fewer car accidents, and better grades. Understanding the science of sleep can help teens make healthier choices.
informational_passages.central_idea: Sleep is crucial for teenage brain development and academic success
supporting_details: Benefits of later school start times

pov_passages.text: While some argue that school uniforms limit self-expression, the benefits far outweigh this concern. Uniforms reduce morning stress for families, eliminate clothing-based bullying, and help students focus on learning rather than fashion. Schools that have implemented uniform policies report improved behavior and a stronger sense of community. Perhaps most importantly, uniforms level the playing field between students from different economic backgrounds.

The stereotype of video games as mindless entertainment is outdated. Research shows that strategic games improve problem-solving skills and hand-eye coordination. Multiplayer games teach teamwork and communication. Some games even inspire interest in history, science, and art. Of course, balance is essential—but dismissing all games as harmful ignores their educational potential.
pov_passages.author_pov: Video games have educational value when used in moderation
